title: Farmers' willingness to pay for Sinar donkey conservation in selected districts of Metekel and Assosa zones, northwest Ethiopia: a contingent valuation study
summary: This paper conducts a contingent valuation study to assess farmers' willingness to pay for Sinar donkey conservation in selected districts of Metekel and Assosa zones, northwest Ethiopia. The study uses descriptive statistics and logistic regression to analyze the data, but does not involve any machine learning or artificial intelligence methods.
methodology: The study employed a contingent valuation approach using structured and semi-structured questionnaires to collect data on socio-economic and farming system characteristics from 160 respondents in two districts. Descriptive statistics were used to summarize the data, and logistic regression was applied to see the effect of independent variables on the dependent variable.
research_outcomes: The study found that farmers' willingness to pay for Sinar donkey conservation is influenced by their cash income, with an average willingness to pay of 98.25 Ethiopian Birr or 3.265US dollars per household per annum.

title: Reward Value-Based Goal Selection for Agents' Cooperative Route Learning Without Communication in Reward and Goal Dynamism
summary: This paper proposes a goal selection method to enable agents to cooperate without communication by adapting to dynamic changes in reward values and goals. The proposed method uses two unified conditions to select the appropriate purposes, making all agents learn to achieve their goals in order of minimum condition value.
methodology: The paper proposes a noncommunicative multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) method based on unified conditions for goal selection. The method makes all agents learn to achieve their purposes in the order of minimum condition values, and each agent learns cooperative policy by PMRL-OM as the previous method.
research_outcomes: The proposed method performs better than PMRL-OM without some conditions in grid world problems. The unified conditions can direct the appropriate goals for agents.

title: Comparison of Random Forest, Logistic Regression, and Multilayer Perceptron Methods on Classification of Bank Customer Account Closure
summary: This paper compares the performance of three machine learning methods (Random Forest, Logistic Regression, and Multilayer Perceptron) in classifying bank customer account closure. The results show that the Multilayer Perceptron method achieves the highest accuracy (85.5373%) and is therefore considered the best model for this task.
methodology: The paper uses a data mining approach with early stage preprocessing to clean data from outliers and missing values, followed by feature selection to select important attributes. The three machine learning methods are then applied to the preprocessed data using 10-fold Cross Validation.
research_outcomes: The Multilayer Perceptron method achieves the highest accuracy (85.5373%) in classifying bank customer account closure, outperforming Random Forest and Logistic Regression methods.

title: Bank competition in China: a blessing or a curse for financial system?
summary: This paper investigates the relationship between bank competition and systematic risk in China, using a dynamic causality model. The study finds a bidirectional causal relationship between banking competition and systematic risk, with both positive and negative effects.
methodology: The authors use a time-varying rolling window approach to estimate the dynamic causality of bank competition and systematic risk in China.
statistics: Granger and sub-sample time varying rolling window
research_outcomes: The results show that increased bank competition leads to reduced systematic risk, supporting the competition-stability hypothesis. However, there is also evidence of reverse causality from systematic risk to banking competition.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning in a Monetary Model
summary: This paper proposes the use of deep reinforcement learning to solve dynamic stochastic general equilibrium models. The authors combine a standard DSGE modeling approach with flexible expectations formation, using modern developments in deep reinforcement learning to enable agents to learn nonlinear decision rules via deep artificial neural networks.
methodology: The authors use a policy-based deep reinforcement learning approach that can deal with high-dimensional continuous action spaces. They apply their proposed approach to a classical model from the adaptive learning literature in macroeconomics, which looks at the interaction of monetary and fiscal policy.
research_outcomes: The results show that when an active fiscal or monetary policy is paired with a passive policy, the corresponding rational expectations equilibria are determinate, and both Adaptively Learning Agent and Artificially Intelligent Agent can learn these equilibria. However, when both monetary and fiscal policy are active (or passive), the corresponding rational expectations equilibria are explosive (or indeterminate), and contrary to the Adaptively Learning Agent, our Artificially Intelligent Agent remains capable of learning these equilibria.

title: On the enrichment of time series with textual data for forecasting agricultural commodity prices
summary: This paper presents a method to enrich time-series data with textual information for forecasting agricultural commodity prices. The authors use a combination of time-series and textual features, including domain-specific terms extracted from texts, to improve the accuracy of their models.
methodology: The proposed method, TSED, combines time-series data with vector representations of texts to enrich the predictive task. The authors use a set of finite terms extracted from texts to represent the textual information and concatenate it with the time-series observations.
statistics: Histogram-based Gradient Boosting Regression (HGBR), Support Vector Regression (SVR), Random Forest Regressor (RF), and Bagging Regressor (BR) are used for regression tasks
research_outcomes: The authors present promising results in several time-series forecasting works, including an increase in performance compared to traditional timeseries forecasting models.

title: Differentiations in Women’s Land Tenure Experiences: Implications for Women’s Land Access and Tenure Security in Sub-Saharan Africa
summary: This paper explores the differentiated land tenure experiences of women in sub-Saharan Africa, highlighting the need for policies to address the heterogeneity of women's situations. The study uses evidence from Ghana, Nigeria, and Zimbabwe to show that women have unique problems, needs, and statuses in their quest for land access and tenure security.
methodology: The study used a mixed-methods approach, combining literature review with empirical qualitative data from fieldwork. The authors collected data at district levels in Ghana and Zimbabwe, and at the local level in Nigeria.
research_outcomes: The findings include a matrix of factors that differentiate women's land access and tenure security, a visualisation of women's differentiation in land tenure showing possible modes for actions, and an adaptable approach for operationalising women's differentiation in land tenure policies.

title: COVID-19 acceleration in digitalisation, aggregate productivity growth and the functional income distribution
summary: This paper examines the impact of COVID-19 on digitalization, aggregate productivity growth, and the functional income distribution in the EU economy. The authors use a two-sector growth model to analyze the effects of a persistent increase in demand for digital services on productivity and inequality.
methodology: The authors extend the standard one-sector neoclassical growth model by distinguishing between conventional and digital sectors, with the latter characterized by fixed costs but low marginal cost.
research_outcomes: The paper finds that a persistent increase in demand for digital services can lead to a reduction of the labour share, particularly if accompanied by a reduction of competition. It also suggests that the digital transition may affect economic sectors and the workforce in differentiated ways, possibly exacerbating the decline in labour shares.

title: Feasibility of nowcasting SDG indicators: a comprehensive survey
summary: This paper explores the feasibility of nowcasting Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) indicators, aiming to address the issue of long publication lags. The authors conducted a comprehensive survey of 362 SDG indicators and sub-indicators, classifying them as highly likely, likely, or unlikely for nowcasting. The study highlights the potential of nowcasting in leveraging timely data from various sources, but also notes concerns over methodology robustness and data validity.
methodology: The authors employed a comprehensive survey approach to assess the nowcasting feasibility of SDG indicators, considering factors such as data availability, publication lags, and explanatory variables.
research_outcomes: The study found that 150 out of 362 surveyed indicators were highly likely to be suitable for nowcasting, while 87 were likely and 125 were unlikely. The authors also highlighted the importance of addressing concerns over methodology robustness and data validity in nowcasting SDG indicators.

title: Tracking COVID-19 Decease Through Rolling Conditional Variance
summary: This paper proposes a tracking indicator for volatility and COVID-19 direction, including a weekly window to observe its evolution. The research aims to track the total deaths caused by COVID-19 in the most affected countries after the approval, distribution, and implementation of vaccines from 2021.
methodology: The authors use an Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) specification as a first adjustment, followed by estimating the conditional variance of total deaths from an Exponential Generalized Autoregressive Conditional Heteroscedasticity (EGARCH).
research_outcomes: The paper proposes a tracking indicator for volatility and COVID-19 direction, including a weekly window to observe its evolution.

title: Based on DPSIR Model Environmental Planning and Risk Evaluation in the Early Stage of State-Level New Areas Development
summary: This paper applies the DPSIR conceptual model to summarize and extract a state-level new Area risk evaluation index system, using traditional statistical methods and high-order mathematical models as comparison. The study identifies 23 risk indicators and uses the adaptability and reliability and validity to test the reliability of the indicator system.
methodology: The DPSIR model is used as a tool to construct a national-level new district risk assessment index system, identifying 23 risk indicators such as 'growth rate of production'. The random forest algorithm is used to explain the general process of State-level New Areas development risk assessment.
statistics: traditional statistical methods and high-order mathematical models
research_outcomes: The study provides a relatively reasonable model explanation for the application of risk assessment in environmental planning, combining the characteristics of the target object. The research outcomes provide strong support for the environmental planning and evaluation of the state-level new Area.

title: Inclusive finance, industrial structure upgrading and farmers’ income: Empirical analysis based on provincial panel data in China
summary: This paper empirically studies the relationship among inclusive finance, industrial structure upgrading and farmers’ income using a panel dataset of 28 provinces in China from 2006 to 2016. The research finds that inclusive finance can significantly promote the increase of farmers’ income through its intermediary mechanism, the Upgrading of Industry Structure (UIS). However, the development model of inclusive finance should be transformed to give full play to its hematopoietic function and guiding role, supporting the UIS.
methodology: Empirical analysis based on provincial panel data
research_outcomes: Inclusive finance can significantly promote farmers’ income through the UIS. The development model of inclusive finance should be transformed to support the UIS.

title: Neural Payoff Machines: Predicting Fair and Stable Payoff Allocations Among Team Members
summary: This paper presents a novel approach to predicting fair and stable payoff allocations among team members using neural networks. The authors combine solution concepts from cooperative game theory with the predictive power of neural networks, creating models that can generalize to games far from the training distribution and predict solutions for more players than observed during training.
methodology: The methodology involves training neural networks on large sets of weighted voting games and computing their respective game theoretic solutions. The authors use a combination of solution concepts from cooperative game theory, including the Shapley value, Banzhaf index, and Least-Core.
statistics: The paper uses statistical methods to analyze the performance of the proposed models and compare them to traditional approaches.
research_outcomes: The research outcomes show that the proposed approach can accurately predict fair and stable payoff allocations among team members, even in games far from the training distribution. The authors also demonstrate the applicability of their approach to feature importance games in explainable AI.

title: Extension Agents Perception of Open Data Usage in Agricultural Communication in Abia State
summary: This paper assesses the perception of open data usage among agricultural extension agents in Abia State, Nigeria. While open data is recognized as a driver for economic growth and a means to facilitate precision agriculture, its use is hindered by challenges such as lack of funding, internet facilities, and adequate knowledge of ICT tools.
methodology: Simple random sampling technique was used to select 83 extension agents. Data was collected using structured questionnaires and analyzed with frequency counts, percentages, and mean.
research_outcomes: The study found that a moderate percentage (68%) of extension agents were aware of open data, but faced challenges such as lack of funding and internet facilities. The use of open data was perceived to facilitate agricultural research, access to research findings, and sharing of information across country borders.
sources_of_inspiration: Open Data in the Agriculture System, 2019

title: Cognitive Sophistication and Deliberation Times
summary: This paper explores the relationship between cognitive sophistication, deliberation times, and behavioral heterogeneity in economics. The authors propose a model that links cognitive effort to choices and deliberation times, using stylized facts from psychophysiological literature on response times. They test this model experimentally in two games commonly used to study iterative thinking.
methodology: The authors use a laboratory experiment to test their model, which incorporates stylized facts from the psychophysiological literature on response times. The experiment involves two games: the beauty contest game and another game.
research_outcomes: The study confirms Predictions 1-4 of the proposed model, providing evidence that deliberation times can be used as a correlate of cognitive effort. The results suggest that increasing incentives leads to more steps of reasoning, but also shorter deliberation times per step.

title: Irrelevant matches in round-robin tournaments
summary: This paper investigates the existence of round-robin tournaments with no irrelevant matches. The authors formalize the notion of relevant and irrelevant matches, and study the circumstances under which relevant tournaments exist. They prove that all tournaments with a static schedule and at least five players include a match that is irrelevant for both agents, but show that dynamic schedules can be devised to avoid irrelevant matches.
methodology: The authors use a probabilistic setting, based on the Bradley-Terry model, to resolve uncertainty about future matches. They also postulate a set of admissibility conditions over preferences, modelling the fact that players aim at outdoing each other.
research_outcomes: The main results are: (1) all tournaments with a static schedule and at least five players include a match that is irrelevant for both agents; (2) for all numbers of players, there is a tournament with a dynamic schedule where all matches are relevant for at least one of the involved players; and (3) all tournaments where all players are called to play with approximately equal frequency (called balanced tournaments) with at least six players include a match that is irrelevant for one of the involved players.

title: Determinants of banks’ cost efficiency: a case study of selected commercial banks, Ethiopia
summary: This paper examines the determinants of cost efficiency in Ethiopian commercial banks using a stochastic frontier analysis. The study focuses on the role of bank-specific and macroeconomic factors in influencing cost efficiency, with no mention of machine learning or artificial intelligence methods.
methodology: The study uses a translog stochastic cost frontier approach to analyze the relative cost efficiency of commercial banks in Ethiopia based on an intermediation approach.
research_outcomes: The findings show that bank-specific factors such as return on assets, intermediation ratio, and capital adequacy ratio have a significant impact on cost efficiency. Macroeconomic factors such as GDP also have a negative but insignificant effect on inefficiency.

title: Real-time Bidding for Time Constrained Impression Contracts in First and Second Price Auctions -- Theory and Algorithms
summary: This paper studies the optimal behavior of a bidder in real-time auctions with time constraints, focusing on first and second price mechanisms. The authors show that the problem can be reduced to a convex optimization problem and provide algorithms for implementing solutions. While ML/AI methods are not explicitly used, the paper's focus on dynamic bidding policies and contract management involves complex statistical estimation problems.
methodology: The authors use convex duality and optimization techniques to analyze the problem and develop practical algorithms for implementation.
statistics: classical control theory methods (e.g., PID controllers), MDP formulations, reinforcement learning
research_outcomes: The paper shows that there is a close connection between first and second price cases, both theoretically and through experimental evidence. The authors also provide detailed simulation evidence and practical methods for adaptation to a stochastic environment.

title: COVID-19 and Its Impacts on Global Economic Spheres
summary: This paper analyzes the socio-economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on global economic spheres, highlighting its effects on GDP, unemployment rates, and poverty. Although the study mentions artificial intelligence, robots, and changing technologies as necessary for survival in critical times, it does not explicitly use or integrate machine learning (ML) methods into its methodology.
methodology: The study uses qualitative and quantitative methods to analyze secondary sources of data and information from scientific and academic journals, scholar articles, research papers, books, and other relevant sources.
research_outcomes: The paper finds that the pandemic has had a significant impact on global economic indicators, including GDP, unemployment rates, and poverty. It also highlights the need for intergovernmental measures to support economies during the pandemic.

title: An Integrated Ecological-Social Simulation Model of Farmer Decisions and Cropping System Performance in the Rolling Pampas (Argentina)
summary: This paper presents an integrated ecological-social simulation model, AgroDEVS, which uses agent-based modeling and Cellular Automata to simulate land-use and cover change (LUCC) dynamics in the Rolling Pampas region of Argentina. The model integrates economic, environmental, and social factors to predict LUCC patterns and their associated economic and environmental changes.
methodology: The authors employed a scenario-based analysis, exploring agricultural mosaic dynamics, and adopted an agent-based modeling approach using the Cell-DEVS formalism. The model was implemented using the CD++ simulation software toolkit.
statistics: Normalized RMSE, Probability of a Match, Index of Observed Fit
research_outcomes: The study found that economic goals were achieved on average each 6 out of 10 years, but environmental thresholds were only achieved in 1.9 out of 10 years. The model proved well-suited to reproduce empirical situations where changes in production/output prices, climate regimes, or farmer aspiration levels occurred.

title: German forecasters' narratives: How informative are German business cycle forecast reports?
summary: This paper analyses the information content of German forecasters' narratives for German business cycle forecasts. The authors apply textual analysis to convert qualitative text data into quantitative sentiment indices, which are then used to test the efficiency of numerical forecasts. While the results suggest some informational content of sentiment indices for growth and inflation forecasts, the predictive power is weak.
methodology: Textual analysis using dictionary methods and text regression methods with recursive estimation
research_outcomes: The study finds that German forecasters' narratives contain some additional information relative to numerical forecasts, but the predictive power is weak.

title: Empirical study and model simulation of global stock market dynamics during COVID-19
summary: This paper empirically studies the impact of COVID-19 on global stock markets, focusing on large volatility dynamics, variation-fluctuation correlation function, and epidemic-fluctuation correlation function. The authors generalize the Heston model to simulate stock market dynamics under the influence of COVID-19.
methodology: Empirical analysis and model simulation using the Heston model
research_outcomes: The study finds that COVID-19 has a significant impact on global stock markets, leading to increased volatility and correlation between oil markets and U.S. stock markets.

title: Modeling Unemployment Duration, Determinants and Insurance Premium Pricing of Malaysia: Insights from an Upper Middle-Income Developing Country
summary: This paper investigates the behavior and determinants of unemployment in Malaysia, an upper middle-income country with relatively low unemployment but rising labor market mismatches. The study uses statistical modeling to estimate unemployment duration and derive a model-based insurance premium pricing schedule that broadens the country's unemployment insurance coverage.
methodology: The paper employs a parametric approach using the Burr distribution, which is fitted to the data set given its superiority over other forms in terms of flexibility. Survival analysis via hazard function corresponding to Burr distribution is used to estimate unemployment duration.
statistics: Burr distribution, Cox proportional hazards model
research_outcomes: The study finds that age, gender, and education are significant explanatory variables of unemployment. The results show that the youngest cohort has the least likelihood of being hired, while the older groups are found to have a lower hazard ratio that could be attributed to work experience.

title: Accumulating Risk Capital Through Investing in Cooperation
summary: This paper proposes a method for training policies that balance safety and cooperation in sequential social dilemmas, using the concept of risk capital to incentivize long-term cooperation. The proposed algorithm, ARCTIC, is shown to be effective in achieving cooperation while maintaining safety in Prisoner's Dilemma and Stag Hunt.
methodology: The authors use reinforcement learning (RL) to train policies that balance safety and cooperation. They propose a method for training policies that targets the objective of accumulating risk capital through investing in cooperation, using policy-conditioned beliefs to incentivize cooperation.
research_outcomes: The paper shows that ARCTIC achieves cooperation while maintaining safety in Prisoner's Dilemma and Stag Hunt. The authors also show that the trade-off between safety and cooperativeness decreases with length of interaction.

title: Proportional Justified Representation
summary: This paper extends the work of Aziz et al. on multi-winner elections by introducing Proportional Justified Representation (PJR), a relaxation of Extended Justified Representation (EJR) that is compatible with perfect representation and can be computed in polynomial time. The authors also show that PJR provides weaker guarantees than EJR regarding average voter satisfaction.
methodology: The paper uses mathematical modeling and proof-based reasoning to analyze the properties of multi-winner voting rules, including PJR and EJR.
research_outcomes: The authors prove that PJR is compatible with perfect representation and can be computed in polynomial time. They also show that PJR provides weaker guarantees than EJR regarding average voter satisfaction.
